snippet: Researchers using themselves as guinea pigs have analyzed huge amounts of their personal data, seeking meaningful and useful patterns.
abstract: Anne Eisenberg Novelties column examines work of Stephen Wolfram, who has begun analyzing hundreds of thousands of pieces of his personal data from decades on the job for his foray into an area he calls personal analytics; says he is among researchers who are seeking meaningful and useful patterns from personal data like e-mails, telephone calls and spikes of writing.
lead_paragraph: Researchers using themselves as guinea pigs have analyzed huge amounts of their personal data, seeking meaningful and useful patterns.

headline.seo: Mining Our Own Personal Data, for Self-Discovery
headline.main: What 23 Years of E-Mail May Say About You
headline.print_headline: What 23 Years of E-Mail May Say About You
